title: Ophir looks offshore with new global fund
text:
“It’s quite easy if you get out there and do the work. You can find there’s these under-researched businesses and you can see they're performing better than the market thinks,” he said.

“Obviously we really like picking businesses we think can become really big in the future. What we're finding is the companies we're investing in are really companies that no one would have heard of in Australia.

“We have a great opportunity to find these businesses but also get them at really cheap prices. We really focus on looking for companies that are under-researched with a big change under way.”

While we've surpassed that 15 per cent in year one, we don't want investors expecting 40 per cent every year. — Andrew Mitchell

The fund’s biggest holding is in email encryption technology provider Zix Group.

“We went and saw it in Dallas. It doesn't really have investor relations, very limited coverage but it’s been growing 20-30 per cent,” Mr Mitchell said.

Zix has a market cap of just under $US400 million ($590 million) and has risen 37.2 per cent in the past 12 months.

“We're quite confident they're performing very well and it has a great management team,” Mr Mitchell said.

The majority of the fund’s holdings are in the US and it has some smaller holdings in Europe, Japan and the UK.

“We've been able to generate good returns but from our perspective what’s more important is what has generated those numbers," Mr Mitchell said

"We've had 60 [earnings] upgrades to six downgrades and that's the best ratio we've ever had in any of our funds.”

'Super growthy'

The biggest sector weighting within the fund is information technology, mirroring a similar weighting to Ophir’s High Conviction Fund, which has large holdings in Afterpay Touch, NEXTDC and Xero.

“Everyone thinks we're super 'growthy' and while our best performing stock last year was Afterpay, not far behind was Austal, which was a value stock,” Mr Mitchell said.

The idea for a global fund had been driven by demand from Ophir's investor base.

Advertisement

"People were always asking us what the next fund would be and because we're seeing the world becoming more globally oriented, trends find their way to Australia faster and faster, and we thought having a global fund would make our Australian investment ability better," Mr Mitchell said.

"It's surpassed our expectations in terms of our investors wanting to back us with the global strategy."

The firm made several key hires during the past year to strengthen its offshore expertise, including bringing in former senior Citi equity research analyst Michael Goltsman and former Brant Point Capital hedge fund manager Tyler Errickson.

Best performers

"We have a great investment group that love the foundational idea based on alignment and getting the best performers for our investors," Mr Mitchell said.

He tempered investor expectations despite the strong performance of the fund in its first year.

“The key thing is we have all our personal money invested, our families and friends are invested in the fund too. We're trying to get 15 per cent [annual return] and we're looking for investors who are in it for the long term. This is the family office for us,” he said.

“While we've surpassed that 15 per cent in year one, we don't want investors expecting 40 per cent every year. We want to under-promise and over-deliver, and as with our other funds, we've been able to beat that 15 per cent to date.”
description: Small and mid-cap manager Ophir Asset Management has been quietly managing a global fund, returning 42 per cent to a handful of investors over the past year.
